top_categories.workout_context: 375 miles. Your legs will beg to quit after 120. This trains the power output you need from mile 130 onward.
35,000ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Oregon Trail Gravel Grinder's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before July.
Oregon Trail Gravel Grinder's High desert gravel, Forest service roads forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 375 miles.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 375 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
At Oregon Trail Gravel Grinder, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
35,000ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
93ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
375 miles rewards fat oxidation. This volume work shifts your fuel mix so you're still burning fat at hour 5, not bonking at hour 3.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 35,000ft of climbing on high desert and forest service gravel across does to your power file on race day.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Oregon Trail Gravel Grinder. Train it until it feels boring.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Oregon Trail Gravel Grinder, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.

race_overlay.nutrition: Ultra-distance fueling for 375 miles: 80–100g carbs/hour from mile 1 — don’t wait until you’re hungry. Practice your exact race-day nutrition in every long training ride. Carry backup calories. 375 miles burns 8,000–12,000+ calories — you cannot replace them all, but you must try.
race_overlay.altitude: Oregon Trail Gravel Grinder with 35,000ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. High-altitude sun exposure.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Oregon Trail Gravel Grinder requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on high desert and forest service gravel across central oregon to build confidence. Expect: high desert gravel, forest service roads, mountain passes.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, VO2max, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 375 miles of high desert and forest service gravel across central oregon in Central Oregon (multiple towns).
